of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  a  country  programming  mission  in  May  2010,  the  Government  of  Bhutan 
requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide an additional technical assistance (TA) 
grant to strengthen the regulatory and supervisory capacity of the Royal Monetary Authority of 
Bhutan  (RMA). Two  previous  grants  had  been  approved  in  2003  and  1999.1 The request 
reflected the government’s efforts to enhance resource mobilization and outreach capacity of 
the financial sector as well as to promote economic and financial governance in accordance 
with  the government’s Tenth  Five-Year  Plan, 2008–2013.2 The TA  was  included  in  ADB’s 
country operations business plan 2011–2013.3 
 
2.  The mission visited Bhutan on 4–6 July 2011, and met with senior officials from the 
Ministry of Finance and RMA. The government and the mission reached an understanding on 
the objectives, scope, financing plan, and implementation details of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Nonbank Financial Institution Architecture 
3.  Nonbank financial institutions account for 9.4% of total assets of the financial sector 
assets as of the end of FY2011. Meanwhile, the nonperforming loan ratio in the nonbank 
financial sector is currently estimated at 7% while that in the banking sector is estimated at 9.5%. 
The two major nonbank financial institutions, Bhutan Development Bank and Royal Insurance 
Corporation of Bhutan, are deeply involved in commercial lending, due to limited investment 
opportunities in the domestic markets and profitability concerns. Bhutan Development Bank 
lends to private sector industrial clients; agricultural businesses; as well as micro, small and 
medium-sized enterprises. The absence of an enabling regulatory and supervisory framework 
for the microfinance sector limits effective delivery of microfinance. Royal Insurance Corporation 
of Bhutan provides life and general insurance. It invests insurance premiums, and its investment 
portfolio is split into (i) credit products, (ii) equity investments, (iii) real estate, and (iv) liquid 
resources. Currently, there is no policy framework encompassing an insurance supervisory 
mechanism. 
 
4.  The  pensions  market  is  relatively  untapped  in  Bhutan.  The  National  Pension  and 
Provident Fund is comprised of a defined benefit pension plan (tier 1) and a defined contribution 
provident fund (tier 2). The National Pension and Provident Fund runs the provident funds for 
the armed forces, state-owned enterprises’ employees, and the civil service. It is expected that 
the organization will be allowed to offer pension products to private individuals in the future. 
Currently, there is no pension regulation and no national pension scheme for the private sector 
or self-employed workers. 
 
5.  The Royal Securities Exchange of Bhutan Limited is subject to supervision by RMA, the 
acting securities commission. The exchange’s rules are approved and amended by RMA. It is 
currently  regulated  by  provisions  under  the  Companies  Act  (2000),  Securities  Exchange

6.  To fill the gaps in the regulation and supervision of Bhutan’s financial sector, RMA, as 
the single regulator, was empowered to license, regulate, and supervise all financial service 
providers. These gaps were especially pronounced in laws and regulations for insurance and 
securities exchanges. A comprehensive Financial Services Act (Act) was enacted in 2011 to 
bring banking, insurance, and securities activities under a unified legislative, regulatory, and 
supervisory framework. In particular, RMA was given powers to address shortcomings and 
issues  in  regulation,  supervision,  and,  in  case  of  violations,  penalties  or  prosecution.  In 
conformity with international standards, the Act includes, among other things, (i) definition of 
insurance solvency margins and admissibility of assets, (ii) securities trading and settlement 
procedures for proper matching and delivery versus payment, (iii) on-site inspection procedure 
of securities exchanges, and (iv) issuer disclosure on control and related-party disclosure plus 
expanded remedies for defective disclosure. In general, because the Act comprises integrated 
financial services legislation, chapters have been drafted to align with current international 
standards in insurance, and securities. It includes, for example, sections entitled Objectives and 
Principles of Securities Regulation and Insurance Core Principles and Methodology.  
 
B.  Limited Human Resource Development of the Royal Monetary Authority of Bhutan 
7.  RMA is significantly constrained by limited human resource development in terms of 
regulating  and  supervising  nonbank  financial  institutions.  This  constraint  has  been  further 
exacerbated with the recent enactment of the new act, which has more detailed and specific 
provisions for insurance and securities as compared to the previous Financial Institution Act. 
Moreover,  additional  new  provisions  are  being  prepared  under  the  World  Bank’s  ongoing 
projects for pensions (pension policy, licensing or registration of pension providers, pension 
supervisory framework) and microfinance (financial inclusion policy, regulatory and supervisory 
framework). The RMA supervisors and stakeholders therefore require specific training in the 
insurance, securities, pension, and microfinance subsectors. 
 
C.  Persistence of Regulatory Gaps in the Nonbank Financial Institution Sector 
  
8.  Regulatory  gaps  persist  despite  progress  in  developing  policies,  provisions,  and 
guidelines for the insurance, securities, pension, and microfinance subsectors. In the insurance 
subsector, regulations need to be formulated on insurance brokerage, licensing of surveyors 
and loss assessors, criteria for actuary appointment, determination of insurance premium as 
well  as  developing  reporting  formats  and  on-site  and  off-site  manuals.  In  the  securities 
subsector, regulations are required in areas such as venture capital, mutual funds, subordinated 
debt and corporate bonds, and derivatives. In the pension subsector, regulations are needed for 
voluntary  saving  schemes  and  the  development  of  on-site  and  off-site  manuals.  In  the 
microfinance subsector, the development of on-site and off-site manuals is needed in addition to 
formulating the regulatory and supervisory framework. 
 
D.  ADB Support for Capacity Building of the Royal Monetary Authority of Bhutan 
 
9.  ADB previously provided capacity development TAs in 1999 and 2003 to strengthen 
RMA’s regulatory and supervisory capacity (footnote 1). The TA in 1999 effectively provided a 
framework for monitoring the health of the banking system by assisting RMA in conducting on-
site and off-site examination of banks, as well as formulating regulatory policy for banks. The TA 
in 2003 was successful in strengthening RMA’s autonomy and supervisory function; building its

3 
good  governance  capacity;  and  improving  the  regulatory  framework  for  RMA,  the  Royal 
Securities Exchange of Bhutan Limited, and other financial institutions. Following successful 
completion of these two TA projects, a follow-up TA project is essential to develop the financial 
sector supervisory and regulatory system for nonbank financial institutions and, since this is an 
area that was not covered by the previous TAs, to address regulatory gaps in the nonbank 
financial institution sector.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be improved overall functioning of the financial sector in Bhutan. This will 
be measured by a reduction of the nonperforming loans in the nonbank sector, an increase in 
capital adequacy for the nonbank sector, an increase in pension coverage, and an increase in 
microfinance penetration. The outcome is enhanced efficiency and effectiveness of the financial 
sector supervisory and regulatory system for nonbank financial institutions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have two outputs: 
 
(i)  Improved  RMA  regulatory  and  supervisory  role.  This  will  assist  RMA  in 
setting regulatory and financial supervisory policy that strikes the right balance in 
formulating effective nonbank financial regulations and rules that would support 
market development while enhancing stability of the Bhutanese financial system 
across the insurance, pension, microfinance, and securities sectors. Training will 
also  be  provided  to  enhance  RMA  staff  expertise  at  both management  and 
departmental levels in terms of drafting nonbank financial regulations as well as 
ensuring effective implementation of these regulations. At least 10 regulations 
pertaining to insurance, securities, pension, and microfinance activities will be 
completed and implemented under this component.  
(ii)  Enhanced  capacity  of  financial  sector.  This will focus on training staff of 
nonbank  financial  institutions  to  ensure  effective  implementation  of,  and 
compliance with, RMA’s new nonbank rules and regulations. This component will 
also focus on training staff from various financial sector entities to ensure they 
are updated about RMA’s new nonbank rules and regulations and contribute to 
broadening  the  expertise  and  capability  of  professionals  across the financial 
sector by disseminating nonbank financial sector knowledge.   
 
12.  It is assumed that the government will continue to give high priority to support regulation 
and supervision practices and that adequate laws and regulations will be prepared on time. A 
major  risk  is  that  laws  and  regulations  will  not  be  properly  implemented  or  enforced.  An 
additional risk would be the nonavailability of relevant staff from nonbank financial institutions 
and other financial sector entities for training purposes.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  RMA will be the executing agency for the TA. It will provide (i) furnished office space for 
the consultants, and access to a conference room; and (ii) local communication facilities for the 
consultants in Thimphu. RMA will provide counterpart staff as necessary. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from May 2012 to May 2013. To achieve 
the planned outcome, 5 international consultants and 1 national consultant will provide a total of 
24.5 person-months of consulting services. The TA will provide (i) one insurance supervision 
expert focused on strengthening the regulatory capacity for supervising the insurance industry, 
(ii)  one  pension  supervision  expert  focused  on  strengthening  the  regulatory  capacity  for 
supervising the pension industry, (iii) one capital market supervision expert with emphasis on 
strengthening  regulatory  capacity  for  supervising  the  capital  market,  (iv)  one  microfinance 
supervision  expert  focused  on  strengthening  the  regulatory  capacity  for  supervising  the 
microfinance industry, (v) one nonbank financial institutions supervision expert focused on off-
site  supervision  and  regulatory  policy,  and  (vi)  one  national  nonbank  financial  institutions 
supervision expert to support all the international consultants. The outline terms of reference for 
consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  Individual  consultants  will  be  hired  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement 
will be done in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Disbursement under the TA project will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
16.  Each international consultant will submit an inception report to RMA and ADB within 2 
weeks of the start of work and a draft final report 2 weeks before the end of the engagement. 
The inception report and finalization of the draft final reports will be discussed at tripartite 
meetings involving RMA, the consultants, and ADB. RMA will provide a brief report as to the 
progress made in supervision activities on a yearly basis for the next 3 years. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $525,000 to the Government 
of  Bhutan  to  be financed  on  a grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund for Poverty  Reduction  for 
Strengthening  Royal  Monetary  Authority’s  Regulatory  Capacity  for  Nonbank  Financial 
Institutions, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Technical Assistance project is designed to strengthen and develop the capacity of 
officers  in  the  nonbank  financial  institutions  (insurance,  pension,  capital  market,  and 
microfinance) and also the regulator of the nonbank financial institution in Bhutan, namely the 
Royal Monetary Authority (RMA). The soundness, stability, and depth of the financial system in 
Bhutan  will  improve  and  ultimately  lead  to  sustained  economic  growth  by  developing  the 
institutional capacity of nonbank financial institutions. 
 
A.   Insurance Supervision Expert (international, 2.5 person-months) 
2.  The  primary  objective  is  to  strengthen  the  regulatory  capacity  for  supervising  the 
insurance  industry  within  RMA,  and  that  would  require:  (i)  preparing  of  a  supervisory 
methodology to support the oversight function, and (ii) training staff in applying the methodology 
and enforcing regulations. For this purpose, it is necessary to prepare standard templates and 
procedures for supervised entities to use in collecting and reporting financial information and 
which would help in building a comprehensive database at RMA. The expert should have 15 
years or more of international professional experience in insurance supervision. He or she will 
submit an inception report to RMA and Asian Development Bank within 2 weeks of the start of 
work and a draft final report 2 weeks before the end of the engagement. 
 
3.  The consultant's responsibilities will include the following: 
(i)  Prepare  a  policy  framework  consisting  of  a  strategic  plan  and  insurance 
supervisory  mechanism.  This  should  involve  discussing  with  RMA  and 
establishing a practical approach to continuously assess the financial health and 
performance of the insurance industry. This includes establishing benchmarks on 
the financial viability of all constituents in the insurance industry, as well as 
evaluating liquidity profile, solvency, asset quality, capital adequacy, earnings 
and management capacity. 
(ii)  Provide hands-on training for staff in on-site examination procedures. This should 
include (a) developing a comprehensive manual for preparing standardized on-
site  examination  reports  and  setting  out  procedures  for  examining  balance 
sheets and financial statements of insurance companies, agents, and brokers 
applicable to the Bhutanese context; and (b) providing guidance notes and/or a 
manual  on  the  various  types  of  enforcement  measures  that  will  assure  the 
correction of weaknesses or violations noted in on-site examinations. 
(iii)  Provide for reporting needs and training for off-site monitoring and analysis. This 
should include 
(a)   developing standardized reporting formats for the insurance companies, 
agents, and brokers; 
(b)  establishing  an  online  (web-based)  reporting  structure  (which  would 
require developing an off-site monitoring system to ensure that the data 
provided  through  reports  are  regularly  reviewed  and  meaningfully 
analyzed); and 
(c)  providing hands-on training and assistance in analyzing and interpreting 
data and information received from insurance companies, agents, and 
brokers and using such information to assess the financial performance of

B.   Pension Supervision Expert (international, 2.5 person-months). 
 
4.  The primary objective is to strengthen the regulatory capacity for supervising the pension 
industry within RMA and that would require (i) preparing a policy and regulatory mechanism and 
framework for the pension industry (in consultation with the World Bank’s first initiative that is 
formulating  an  overall  pension  regulatory  framework),  (ii)  preparing  of  a  supervisory 
methodology to support the oversight function, and (iii) training staff in applying the methodology 
and enforcing regulations. For this purpose, it is necessary to prepare standard templates and 
procedures for supervised entities to use in collecting and reporting financial information and 
which would help in building a comprehensive database in RMA. The expert should have 15 
years or more of international professional experience in pension supervision. He or she will 
submit an inception report to RMA and ADB within 2 weeks of the start of work and a draft final 
report 2 weeks before the end of the engagement. 
 
5.  The consultant's responsibilities will include the following: 
(i)  Prepare  a  policy  framework  consisting  of  a  strategic  plan  and  pension 
supervisory  mechanism.  This  should  involve  discussing  with  RMA  and 
establishing a practical approach to continuously assess the financial health and 
performance of the pension industry. This includes establishing benchmarks on 
the  financial  viability  of  all  constituents  in  the  pension  industry,  as  well  as 
evaluating liquidity profile, solvency, asset quality, capital adequacy, earnings 
and management capacity. 
(ii)  Provide hands-on training for staff in on-site examination procedures. This should 
include (a) developing a comprehensive manual for preparing standardized on-
site  examination  reports,  and  setting  out  procedures  for  examining  balance 
sheets  and  financial  statements  of  pension  companies,  agents,  and  brokers 
applicable to the Bhutanese context; and (b) providing guidance notes and/or a 
manual  on  the  various  types  of  enforcement  measures  that  will  assure  the 
correction of weaknesses or violations noted in on-site examinations. 
(iii)  Provide for reporting needs and training for off-site monitoring and analysis. This 
should include:

(iv)  Assist in implementing, interpreting, and enforcing regulations and circulars. 
(v)  Assist in implementing international best practice standards in financial reporting

(vi)  Establish  a  regular  (monthly)  discussion  forum  with  all  stakeholders  in  the

(vii)  Produce  and  present  to  RMA  (a)  a  procedure  manual  to  be  followed  in 
conducting on-site and off–site examinations, (b) a recommended supervisory 
methodology to support RMA’s oversight function, and (c) on-the-job training 
materials for staff in implementing the supervisory methodology. 
(viii)  Develop standard templates and procedures for collecting information through 
regular reports and returns submitted by supervised entities. 
(ix)  Train staff to analyze data and information submitted by pension companies, 
agents, and brokers. 
 
C.   Capital Market Supervision Expert (international, 2.5 person-months). 
 
6.  The primary objective is to strengthen the regulatory capacity for supervising the capital 
market within RMA, and that would require (i) preparing a supervisory methodology to support 
the  oversight  function,  and  (ii)  training  staff  in  applying  the  methodology  and  enforcing 
regulations. The expert should have significant experience (a minimum of 15 years) in capital 
market regulation in developed and developing markets, as well as working knowledge of 
implementing  the  best  practice  principles  and  objectives  in  securities  regulation  of  the 
International Organization of Securities Commissions. Experience in the Asia and Pacific region 
is preferable. The principal aim of this assignment is to strengthen the regulatory framework 
governing Bhutan’s capital market. This will involve establishing suitable supervisory policies, 
rationalizing institutional responsibilities across different products and sectors, and identifying 
any legal implications. The expert should have 15 years or more of international professional 
experience in capital market supervision. He or she will submit an inception report to RMA and 
ADB within 2 weeks of the start of work and a draft final report 2 weeks before the end of the 
engagement. 
 
7.  The expert’s responsibilities will also include the following: 
 
(i)  Examine the current regulatory framework and structure of the capital market in 
Bhutan,  while  focusing  on  the  efficacy  of  regulatory  oversight  mechanisms, 
enforcement and monitoring.  
(ii)  Clarify gaps and impediments to the development of the capital market on the 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
basis of best practice principles.  
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
(iii)  Consult with all stakeholders concerned to provide regulatory reforms options to 
provide  the  most  feasible  institutional  structure  in  terms  of  regulation  and 
supervision. While considering this, he or she will identify arrangements that

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
strengthen  internal  governance  so  that  the  regulatory  system  can  operate 
effectively. 
(iv)  Consider  options  for  benchmarking  regulatory  efforts  against  international 
standards. 
 
D.   Microfinance Supervision Expert (international, 2.5 person-months). 
 
8.  The  primary  objective  is  to  strengthen  the  regulatory  capacity  for  supervising  the 
microfinance industry within RMA, and that would require (i) preparing a policy and regulatory 
mechanism and framework for the microfinance industry (in consultation with the World Bank’s 
Private Sector Development Project), (ii) preparing a supervisory methodology to support the 
oversight function, and (iii) training staff in applying the methodology and enforcing regulations. 
For this purpose, it is necessary to prepare standard templates and procedures for supervised 
entities to use in collecting and reporting financial information and which would help in building a 
comprehensive database at RMA. The expert should have 15 years or more of international 
professional experience in microfinance supervision. He or she will submit an inception report to 
RMA and ADB within 2 weeks of the start of work and a draft final report 2 weeks before the end 
of the engagement. 
 
9.  The consultant's responsibilities will include the following: 
(i)  Prepare  a  policy  framework  consisting  of  a  strategic  plan  and  microfinance 
supervisory  mechanism.  This  should  involve  discussing  with  RMA  and 
establishing a practical approach to continuously assess the financial health and 
performance of the microfinance industry. This includes establishing benchmarks 
on the financial viability of all constituents in the microfinance industry, as well as 
evaluating liquidity profile, solvency, asset quality, capital adequacy, earnings 
and management capacity. 
(ii)  Provide hands-on training for staff in on-site examination procedures. This should 
include (a) developing a comprehensive manual for preparing standardized on-
site  examination  reports  and  setting  out  procedures  for  examining  balance 
sheets and financial statements of microfinance companies applicable to the 
Bhutanese context, and (b) providing guidance notes and/or a manual on the 
various  types  of  enforcement  measures  that  will  assure  the  correction  of 
weaknesses or violations noted in on-site examinations. 
(iii)  Provide for reporting needs and training for off-site monitoring and analysis. This 
should include 
(a)  developing  standardized  reporting  formats  for  the  microfinance 
companies, 
(b)  establishing  an  online  (web-based)  reporting  structure  (would  require 
developing an off-site monitoring system to ensure that the data provided 
through reports are regularly reviewed and meaningfully analyzed, and 
(c)  providing hands-on training and assistance in analyzing and interpreting 
data and information received from microfinance companies and using 
such information to assess the financial performance of the constituents 
by means of ratios and trend analyses. 
(iv)  Establish  procedures  and  guidelines  in  licensing  microfinance  companies 
including to provide a framework to be followed in reviewing licensing procedure. 
(v)  Assist in implementing, interpreting, and enforcing regulations and circulars. 
(vi)  Assist in implementing international best practice standards in financial reporting 
by the microfinance companies.

Appendix 3  13 
(vii)  Establish  a  regular  (monthly)  discussion  forum  with  all  stakeholders  in  the 
industry and discuss policy and operational matters. 
(viii)  Produce  and  present  to  RMA  (a)  a  procedure  manual  to  be  followed  in 
conducting  on-site  and  off-site  examinations  and  including  procedures  for 
licensing institutions, (b)  a recommended  supervisory methodology to support 
RMA’s  oversight  function,  and  (c)  on-the-job  training  materials  for  staff  in 
implementing the supervisory methodology.  
(ix)  Develop standard templates and procedures for collecting information through 
regular reports and returns submitted by supervised entities. 
(x)  Train staff to analyze data and information submitted by microfinance companies. 
 
E.   Nonbank  Financial  Institutions  Supervision  Expert  with  Experience  in  Off-Site 
  Supervision and Regulatory Policy (international, 2.5 person-months).  
 
10.  The primary objective is to formulate policy objectives for nonbank financial institution 
supervision and prudential guidelines. Policies and practices will also be developed with regard 
to licensing of nonbank financial institutions. The expert should have 15 years or more of 
international professional experience in nonbank financial institutions supervision. The expert 
will submit an inception report to RMA and ADB within 2 weeks of the start of work and a draft 
final report 2 weeks before the end of the engagement. 
 
11.  The consultant will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)  Serve  as  an  adviser  to  RMA’s  deputy  governor  on  supervision  matters  for 
nonbank  financial  institutions,  and  assist  RMA  in  formulating  clearly  defined 
policy  objectives  for  nonbank  financial  institution  supervision  and  prudential 
guidelines. 
(ii)  Review  the  appropriateness  of  the  organization  and  activities  performed  by 
RMA's  Financial  Institution  Supervision  Division.  Review  career  development 
opportunities for bank supervision staff, then make appropriate recommendations 
to ensure that nonbank supervision is considered a career stream and is staffed 
by professional bank supervisors. 
(iii)  Further  develop  policies  and  practices  related  to  the  licensing  of  nonbank 
financial institutions. 
(iv)  Review  and  develop  the  off-site  supervision  function.  Review  the  existing 
periodical returns submitted by supervised entities and recommend modifications 
where appropriate. 
(v)  Design and develop the format of the reports to be produced.  
(vi)  Identify training needs of the supervisors and assist in finding suitable off-site 
training courses at international training institutes. 
 
F.   Nonbank Financial Institutions Supervision expert (national, 12.0 person-months).  
 
12.  The primary objective is to provide support to the international consultants as well as 
training  support  to  relevant  stakeholders.  The  expert  should  have  10  years  or  more  of 
international and national professional experience in nonbank financial institutions supervision. 
 
13.  The consultant will have the following responsibilities:
